item.title: Fehler Files: Talking about talking in German
item.description: Clawing my brain apart trying to remember whether a verb takes the dative or accusative case is one of those universal German-learning struggles that I imagine inspired the whole “Deutsche Sprache, schwere Sprache” idea. And I’ve noticed that many of the words that most often initiate a holy-$h!#-what-case-do-I-use death-spiral are the common verbs describing speech: sagen, fragen, and co. The funny thing is, these verbs actually mostly–and I’ll’get to the mostly bit–behave according to the usual rules dictating case in German.
